headline: A surging far right cements its place in Europe
context: LONDON — If Donald Trump wins the U.S. presidential election next month, he will find across the Atlantic a hotbed of political parties that share his rightward mix of authoritarianism, populism and extreme hostility to immigration.

This is the rise of the European far right, which reached a high-water mark on Sept. 29 when Austria’s Freedom Party won the largest share of votes — 28.9 % — in the national election. The FPÖ, as it’s known, was founded by former Nazis and wants to “remigrate” Austrian nationals with migrant roots to create a more “homogenous” society.

annotations.paragraph: This is not a new trend, and its current cycle has been covered by NBC News and others for at least a decade. But the last 12 months have been a bonanza for this former fringe of the political spectrum. There have been big wins for France’s National Rally, led by Marine Le Pen, as well as for Dutch anti-Islam radical Geert Wilders and the neighboring Alternative for Germany, which is being monitored by Berlin’s own intelligence agency for suspected extremism.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides specific examples of far-right political successes in Europe, contributing to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: “The overall trend is unmistakable: The far right is gaining ground,” said Matthijs Rooduijn, a politics professor at the University of Amsterdam. European “far-right parties are here to stay,” agreed Cas Mudde, a professor of international affairs at the University of Georgia and the author of 2019’s “The Far Right Today.”
annotations.reason: The paragraph includes expert commentary that supports the article's main premise about the rise of the far right in Europe.

annotations.paragraph: Some scholars trace the roots of this surge to two events: the global financial crisis of 2007-08 and the 2015 spike in migration into Europe, fueled by wars and unrest across the Middle East and North Africa. The economic crash left Europeans poorer, with crumbling public services and infrastructure. The border crisis added to that a rapid influx of people, many from Muslim-majority countries.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the historical and socio-economic factors contributing to the rise of the far right in Europe.

annotations.paragraph: It’s a familiar cocktail: an economically beleaguered population turning to racism as a salve. In recent decades, rises in immigration during economic downturns have pushed “voters to the most extreme version of the far right, blaming immigrants for unemployment,” according to a 2018 study in the London peer-reviewed journal Electoral Studies.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the historical pattern of far-right support during economic downturns.

annotations.paragraph: Today is no different, with historic inflation rates, the erosion of social programs and Europe’s energy crisis stoking economic angst.
annotations.reason: Links current economic issues to the rise of far-right sentiment in Europe.

annotations.paragraph: “Indigenous people are being ignored because of the mass immigration,” Wilders, leader of the Dutch Party for Freedom, said last year. “We have to think about our own people first now. Borders closed. Zero asylum-seekers.”
annotations.reason: Includes a direct quote from a far-right leader, illustrating their stance on immigration.

annotations.paragraph: Wilders, who rejects the “far right” label, has previously called Islam “the ideology of a retarded culture” and once suggested an annual “head-rag tax” of 1,000 euros (about $1,100) for anyone wearing Islamic clothing.
annotations.reason: Provides specific examples of Wilders' controversial statements, relevant to the far-right narrative.

annotations.paragraph: A hop over into France, Le Pen has attempted to soften her party’s image from the days when, in 2010, she likened Muslim street prayers to the Nazi occupation of France. Still, in 2017, she called France “a university for jihadists,” alleging it had become an incubator for Islamist terrorism.
annotations.reason: Discusses Le Pen's efforts to rebrand her party and her controversial statements, relevant to the far-right context.

annotations.paragraph: NBC News contacted Wilders’ and Le Pen’s parties for comment on the criticisms against them.
annotations.reason: This paragraph does not provide new information or context related to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: The Alternative for Germany party, which is polling in second place in that country, said in an email that “terms like ‘right-wing extremist,’ ‘Islamophobic’ or ‘nationalist’ are only intended to distract from the real problems in this country.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides direct commentary from a relevant political party, contributing to the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: It said it “advocates the preservation of democracy” and claims it sees German citizens as equal “regardless of someone’s ethnic or cultural background.” However, the party said it “clearly opposes an Islamist religious practice that is directed against the free democratic basic order, our laws and against the Judeo-Christian and humanistic foundations of our culture.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers insight into the party's stance, relevant to the article's focus on far-right ideologies.

annotations.paragraph: It’s not just Muslims the AfD has offended. This year, its leader, Björn Höcke, was found guilty of knowingly using a Nazi slogan — “Everything for Germany!” — at a 2021 rally.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about the party's controversial actions, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: These parties often share Trumpian protectionist policies — from backing trade tariffs to opposing arming Ukraine — as well as economic populism, aspects of which have been more traditionally associated with the left: supporting pensions and social services, raising some taxes on the wealthy while lowering them for the working class, or price controls on rent and food during periods of high inflation.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the policies of far-right parties, relevant to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: Their most distinguishing platform, however, is not just their opposition to immigration, but also their suggestion that European culture and values are being replaced by those of others.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the ideology of the far-right parties, which is central to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: This “ideology of ethnic replacement” and “demographic redefinition,” which the parties are seeking to solve with an “expulsion of migrants,” sounds “awful when you think of the Nazism of the past,” said Nadia Urbinati, a politics professor at Columbia University.
annotations.reason: The paragraph includes a relevant expert quote that provides context and historical comparison to the far-right ideology.

annotations.paragraph: Though mainstream parties often revile these policies and rhetoric, they have been nudged toward them by the electoral threat looming on their rightward flank. In Britain, the traditionally center-left Labour Party won an election in July while adopting a hard line on immigration and championing flag-waving “patriotic” values — something leftists saw as dog-whistle nationalism.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides examples of how mainstream parties are influenced by far-right policies, which is relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: “The ideas of these parties have been legitimized by many mainstream right-wing parties, and political as well as media discourse has shifted to the right,” said Rooduijn, of the University of Amsterdam. “What was once considered radical has now become the new normal for many voters.”
annotations.reason: The paragraph includes a relevant expert quote that discusses the normalization of far-right ideas, contributing to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: In Europe’s multiparty arena, center-right and center-left parties tended to dominate the postwar era, with greens, pro-business “liberals” and the far right and left in smaller roles. But recent elections have seen the far right increasingly usurp centrist conservatives as the main right-wing force.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context and recent electoral trends, which are relevant to understanding the rise of the far right in Europe.

annotations.paragraph: Observers once thought the limit of their vote share was around 20%, said Markus Wagner, a politics professor at the University of Vienna. “But that potential upper limit just keeps increasing.”
annotations.reason: Provides expert commentary on the increasing vote share of far-right parties.

annotations.paragraph: The far right is “no longer second fiddle to the main right-wing party. This really changes the dynamic of how parties compete,” Wagner said. “It seems plausible that we are moving towards a world where the main party on the right in many countries is a far-right party.”
annotations.reason: Offers analysis on the changing political dynamics due to the rise of far-right parties.

annotations.paragraph: Europe’s multiparty system has also held a shred of optimism for the mainstream, at least in the short term. Centrists can sometimes cobble together coalitions to keep out the far right — even if those parties are smaller individually.
annotations.reason: Discusses the potential for centrist coalitions to counteract the far right, relevant to the political landscape.

annotations.paragraph: In Austria, most have refused to form a coalition with the FPÖ. The former ruling conservatives, the Austrian People’s Party, said they would only consider it if the FPÖ’s leader, Herbert Kickl, is not included.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about coalition dynamics in Austria related to the far right.

annotations.paragraph: Whereas in France, Le Pen was kept from victory in June-July parliamentary elections by an intricate network of tactical voting between erstwhile rivals.
annotations.reason: Details a specific instance of tactical voting in France to prevent far-right success.

annotations.paragraph: This type of dealmaking comes with risks.
annotations.reason: The paragraph is vague and does not provide specific information related to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: “The question is how to respond to the growing right while remaining consistent with electoral democracy,” said Urbinati. “Not respecting the will of the voters is a dangerous sign of weakness and arrogance.”
annotations.reason: The quote provides direct commentary on the challenges of responding to the rise of the far right, which is relevant to the article's focus.
